title-group.article-title: Data Mining of Spatial–Temporal Expression of Genes in the Human Endometrium During the Window of Implantation

article-meta.aff: 1Institute of Obstetrics and Gynecology Hospital, Fudan University, Shanghai, China
2Obstetrics and Gynecology Hospital, Fudan University, Shanghai, China
3Health Center for Women and Children, Chang ning district, Shanghai, China

author-notes.corresp: Wei Zhang, Institute of Obstetrics and Gynecology Hospital, Fudan University, 413 Zhaozhou Road, Shanghai, China, 200011 Email: zhang.wei.fudan@gmail.com

abstract.p: Previous studies of microarrays have produced mass data that are far from fully applied. To make full use of the available mass data and to avoid redundancy and unnecessary waste, we employed bioinformatics tools GeneSifter and Ingenuity Pathway Analysis (IPA) to mine and annotate 45 microarrays related to endometrium receptivity from GEO (Gene Expression Omnibus) database. In total, 1543 gene sets were found to express differentially, of which 148 highly regulated genes were listed as potential biomarkers of the receptive endometrium. The function and pathway analysis identified the differentially expressed genes primarily involved in immune response and cell cycle. Two networks related to the cardiovascular system and cancers were generated within the genes which changed more than 10-fold. Nine genes were validated by real-time polymerase chain reaction. It was a meaningful exploration of the existing data to acquire useful and reliable information, and our results undoubtedly provided valuable clues for further studies.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Successful implantation demands an outstanding synchronization between the embryonic development and the differentiation of endometrium. The viable blastocyst and the receptive endometrium are the two necessary conditions. 1 The endometrium is receptive only during the window of implantation which approximately lasts 4 days (day 20-23), equal to the time of middle secretory phase in a normal 28-day menstrual cycle in human beings. 2 In the process of receptivity establishment, the endometrium undergoes extensive morphological, physiological, and molecular biological changes to facilitate embryo implantation, which are precisely regulated by endocrine, paracrine, and autocrine signals. 3
–9 Disturbance of endometrial receptivity composes one of the major factors of assisted reproductive technology (ART) failure and unexplained infertility. If we can find ways to pinpoint the restricted period and ensure the embryo transfer with the right time of optimal endometrial receptivity, the ART, the diagnosis and treatment of unexplained infertility can be significantly promoted. Therefore, there is an underlying necessity to discover specific markers that may serve as molecular targets for imaging the endometrial receptivity. To achieve this, researchers have made great efforts in recent years. The past two decades have witnessed an explosive growth in the amount of genomic studies, which resulted in unprecedented amount of data accumulated. 10
–17 Despite vigorous research efforts, the reliable diagnostic markers are still lacking and the molecular mechanism under the endometrial receptivity remains unclear.

Bioinformatics, a newly emerging cross-discipline which employs computer technologies and statistical methods to manage and analyze the huge volume of biological data, has been widely used for biomarker discovery, prognosis, and analysis of molecular mechanism of diseases or special conditions. 18
–21 The development of bioinformatics would open the possibility for efficiently utilizing the unprecedented amount of the previous data. In the present study, therefore, we sought to get more valuable and accurate information by integrating and analyzing the mass existing data, which may help discover specific biomarkers and illuminate the molecular mechanism of the receptive endometrium.

sec.title: Data Collection
sec.p: After searching the two biggest microarray data repositories, GEO (http:// www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo/) and ArrayExpress (http://www.ebi.ac.uk/microarray-as/ae/), 18 total of 45 samples from 3 studies (GSE 4888, 17 GSE 6364, 22 and GSE 730523) using the same platform Affymetrix Human Genome U133 plus 2.0 Array (HG-U133_Plus_2, total 54 675 probe sets) were selected for analysis, of which 17 were collected from the proliferative phase, 6 from early secretory phase, 16 from mid-secretory phase, and 6 from late secretory phases (Table 1). The data of disease groups from GSE6364 and GSE7305 were removed and the remaining were all the normal samples. All the endometrial biopsies were obtained by pipelle catheter, biopsy, or curetting hysterectomy specimens from women with normal menstrual cycle and without steroid hormone medications within 3 months. The indications for the operative procedures in which the samples were obtained included uterine prolapsed, uterine leiomyomata, normal volunteers, pelvic pain, and ovarian cyst. None of the participants had endometriosis. The classification was performed against pathological criteria. Total RNAs were extracted, amplified, and hybridized onto Affymetrix microarrays, and the chips were scanned using the HR3000 scanner from Affymetrix.

caption.p: Source of Samples in this Study

fn.p: Abbreviations: PE, proliferative endometrium; ESE, early secretory endometrium; MSE, mid-secretory endometrium and LSE, late secretory endometrium.

sec.title: Identification of differently expressed genes
sec.p: To determine spatial–temporaral expression of genes in MSE, the downloaded CEL files were uploaded onto GeneSifter program (www.genesifter.net) using robust microarray analysis (RMA) for background adjustment, normalization, and log2 transformation of perfect match values. 19 Project analysis was used to identity differentially expressed genes based on the following parameters: global median normalization, a quality cutoff of 0.75, a fold-change threshold of 2.0, and a Kruskal-Wallis test among groups followed by Benjamini-Hochberg posttest to limit a false discovery rate ≤5%. To further find the most highly changed genes to facilitate biomarker discovery, we adjusted the fold-change threshold from 5 to 10. Principal component analysis (PCA) was used to examine the complexities of the multivariate data. 20 Subsequently, hierarchical clustering (condition tree) was applied to the data files. 21,24 The chromosome analysis was carried out by another module of Genesifter, which allowed the user to view all the selected genes gathered by chromosome distribution in a project.

sec.title: Functional analysis of differentially expressed genes
sec.p: GeneSifter provides gene ontology (GO) analysis tool, a major bioinformatics initiative with the aim of standardizing the representation of gene and gene product attributes across species and databases, which can be used to interpret biological, molecular, and cellular functions of these differentially expressed genes. A z score report is provided to statistically evaluate the results, showing how much the ontology is over- or under- represented in a gene list: positive z scores indicating the given GO category with more genes meeting the criterion than is expected by chance, as in the case of the negatives, and those near zero suggesting that the number of genes approximates to the expected number. 17

sec.title: Pathway and network analysis
sec.p: For further understanding their complexity, differentially expressed genes were uploaded onto ingenuity software for analysis (www.ingenuity.com). Canonical pathway analysis identified the pathways from the Ingenuity Pathway Analysis (IPA) library of canonical pathways that were most significant to the data set. The genes from the data set that met the fold-change cutoff of 2 in association with a canonical pathway in Ingenuity Knowledge Base were considered for analysis. The significance of the association between the data set and the canonical pathway was measured in 2 ways: a ratio of the number of molecules from the data set that map to the pathway divided by the total number of molecules that map to the canonical pathway is displayed; Fisher exact test was used to calculate a P value determining the probability that the association between the genes in the data set and the canonical pathway is explained by chance alone (www.ingenuity.com company/pdf/Citation Guidelines). 21,24

Network analysis was used to exhibit the relationships between those highly regulated genes. Since the size of the created gene network could potentially be enormous, the number of molecules was limited to 35, leaving only the most important ones based on the number of connections for each focus gene (focus genes = a subset of uploaded significant genes having direct interactions with other genes in the database) to other significant genes. 25 To be concise, a set of data containing the so-called highly regulated genes which changed over 10-fold and corresponding expression values were uploaded for network analysis. Each identifier was mapped to its corresponding object in Ingenuity’s Knowledge Base. The networks of these focus genes were algorithmically generated based on their connectivity.

sec.title: Data Validation
sec.p: The endometrial samples (n = 18) were obtained from fertile women by pipelle catheter when they underwent colposcopy examination for cervical benign lesions, which was confirmed by pathology. The inclusion criteria for the participants were as follows: aging from 24 to 41 years, having regular cycles (27-33 days), and without steroid hormone medications within 3 months. The procedures were conducted after obtaining a written informed consent from the participants and the study protocol was approved by the Committee of Fudan University Obstetrics and Gynecology Hospital on the Use of Human Subjects in Medical Research. The samples were kept on ice and transported to the laboratory immediately. The portions of tissues were routinely embedded in optimal cutting temperature compound, and then frozen blocks underwent hematoxylin and eosin staining and histological evaluation was conducted blindly by 2 independent pathologists. The specimens were assigned, according to the criteria of Noyes et al, 26 as PE (proliferative endometrium, days 8-14, n = 6), ESE (early secretory endometrium, days 15-18, n = 4), MSE (mid-secretory endometrium, days 19-23, n = 5), and LSE (late secretory endometrium, days 24-28, n = 3).

Other portions were snap frozen in liquid nitrogen for RNA isolation before reverse transcription, and real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR) were employed for validation of the selected genes. The primers were designed using online software Primer 3 at http://frodo.wi.mit.edu/ (Table 2); the complementary DNA (cDNA) was generated using RevertAidTM First Strand cDNA Synthesis Kit (Fermentas, Canada) as indicated by the manufacturer’s protocol; quantitative PCR was performed with SYBR Premix Ex Taq (Takara, China), detected by ABI PRISM 7500HT system (Applied Biosystem, California, USA); and the gene expressions of selected genes, normalized to those of the glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase in all samples. All experiments were performed in triplicate.

caption.p: Primers Used for Real-Time PCR Validation

sec.p: Genes were selected for validation because of their highly significant P value or FC (fold change) and/or because more than one probe set of the same gene whose expressions were significantly different. The selection occurred also on the ground of previously published data on gene expression studies related to endometrial receptivity.

Data analysis was conducted using the relative expression algorithm, and statistical analysis was performed via one-way analysis of variance followed by LSD (least significant difference) analysis with SPSS 16.0 software. The values were considered statistically significant at P ≤ .05.

sec.title: Expression Analysis of Genes in MSE
sec.p: When a minimal change of 2-fold was adopted as the threshold, 1543 of 54 675 gene sets were identified to express differentially in MSE. The PCA of the expression profiles demonstrated a clear segregation of PE from the other 3 secretory phases, and the distance between MSE and LSE was closer than that between ESE and MSE (Figure 1).

caption.p: Principal components analysis (PCA) using the genes with over 2-fold change through the 4 menstrual phases. Expression between PE and the other 3 secretory phases was distinguishable along the first principal components axis, whereas the others were defined by the second principal components axis, and the distance between MSE and LSE was closer than that between ESE and MSE. PE indicates proliferative endometrium; ESE, early secretory endometrium; MSE, mid-secretory endometrium; LSE, late secretory endometrium.

sec.p: Hierarchical cluster analysis identified the profile of the spatial–temporal expression of genes, of which 999 were upregulated and 544 were downregulated in MSE (Figure 2). When the threshold was adjusted to a 5-fold change, a total of 148 gene sets, 73 up- and 75 downregulated, were listed as candidate biomarkers of the endometrium in MSE (Tables 3 and 4).

caption.p: The Genes Changed More Than 5-Fold and With the Highest Expression in MSEa

The genes were meeting the 2-fold change cutoff of log ratio with a P < .05.

a All the genes were listed by alphabetic order. The genes over 10-fold change are in boldface, and the number in the parentheses indicated the fold change.
b More than 1 gene set of the corresponding genes changed.

sec.p: The chromosome analysis found that the differentially expressed genes distributed in chromosomes 4, 9, and 14 with a high z score >2, indicating that more genes were located in these 3 chromosomes than expected by chance (Table 5).

caption.p: The Chromosome Analysis of the Differentially Expressed Genes

fn.p: a The number in the column of list displays the amount of the differentially expressed genes located in the corresponding chromosome and the number in the column of gene set represents the amount of all genes existing in the microarray and located in the corresponding chromosome. The genes used for this analysis met the 2-fold cutoff of log ratio with a P value ≤.05.

sec.title: Functional Analysis of the Differentially Expressed Genes in MSE
sec.p: Gene ontology analysis of the upregulated genes manifested that they were mainly assembled in the following biological processes: responses to wounding, response to stimulus and stress, and inflammation; that their molecular functions included signal transducer activity, oxidoreductase activity, and cytoskeletal protein binding; and that their cellular components were primarily located at the plasma membrane, desmosome, extracellular region, and cell–cell junction. On the other hand, the downregulated genes were mainly assembled in these biological processes: cell cycle, cell division, and cytoskeleton organization; their molecular functions basically comprised microtubule motor activity, binding, and metallopeptidase activity; their cellular components mainly involved spindle, condensed chromosome, and microtubule cytoskeleton (Table 6).

caption.p: Enriched GO Categories of the Differentially Expressed Genesa

fn.p: a Only the top 10 categories of each classification have been listed in this table. The genes used for this analysis met the 2-fold cutoff of log ratio with a P value ≤.05.

sec.title: Canonical Pathway and Network Analysis
sec.p: Two canonical pathways, complement system and mitotic roles of polo-like kinase (Plk) pathway, were found to be highly regulated in MSE. Furthermore, the genes that participated in the former were mainly upregulated, whereas those in the latter were downregulated together (Figure 3). Two significant networks, mainly related to cardiovascular system and cancers, were generated using the highly regulated genes which changed over 10-fold (Table 7, Figure 4).

caption.p: Canonical pathway analysis of the differentially expressed genes. Ingenuity pathway analysis identifying 2 most significant pathways from the data set; (A) the mitotic roles of polo-like kinase pathway; (B) the complement system pathway; red: upregulated genes, green: downregulated genes, and white: genes with no changes. The genes were from GeneSifter meeting the 2-fold change cutoff of log ratio with a P < .05.

A: network related to cardiovascular system development and function, organismal development, cellular growth, and proliferation; (B) network about cancer, reproductive system disease, and tumor morphology. Red: upregulated genes, green: downregulated genes, white: genes with no changes. The genes were from GeneSifter meeting the 10-fold change cutoff of log ratio with a P < .05.
Networks Indentified by the Ingenuity Pathway Analysisa

tr.td: ACTA1, ADAM12, AKT1, CFD, CNN1, DEFB1, ERBB2, ERK1/2, IDO1, IFNG, IL4, IL13, IL1B, INHBA, IRF1, ITGB1, interferon a, JUNB, LEFTY1, MAOA, MMP3, MMP11, MYC, MYOCD, PLAU, SERPINE1, SMAD7, SMAD2/3, STAT1, TAGLN, TNF, TOP2A, TGFB1, TGFBR2, TP53

fn.p: a The highly regulated genes are in boldface. The genes used for this analysis met the 10-fold cutoff of log ratio with a P value ≤ .05.

sec.title: Data Validation
sec.p: Nine genes, DKK1, S100P, MAOA, FAM48A, CXCL14, SFRP4, SFN, ANXA4, and CRISP3, were chosen for validation by real-time PCR (Figure 5). The results accorded with those from data mining.

caption.p: Expression profile of selected genes CXCL14 (a), FAM148A (b), MAOA (c), S100P (d), ANXA4 (e), SFN (f), CRISP3(g), DKK1(h), and SFRP4 (i) exhibited by GeneSifter after analyzing the 45 microarray samples; mRNA levels for CXCL14 (A), FAM148A (B), MAOA (C), S100P (D), D ANXA4 (E), SFN (F), CRISP3(G), DKK1(H), and SFRP4 (I) in samples from fertile women examined by quantitative PCR using GAPDH as the housekeeping gene. The results were normalized relative to that of PE (mean ± SD; *P < .05). mRNA indicates messenger RNA; PCR, polymerase chain reaction; GAPDH, glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase; SD, standard deviation.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In the present study, we integrated microarray data from multicenter for the first time to decipher gene expression profile, search for potential biomarkers, and explore the possible mechanism of the endometrial receptivity in the “window of implantation.”

sec.title: The Advantages of Bioinformatics
sec.p: Genomics and proteomics have been widely applied to the research on endometrial receptivity. Because of the nature of the data, for example, high technical variability, small sample volume, and high dimension size, the results of high-throughput data were not highly reliable, and there was only 1 single gene, secreted phosphoprotein 1 (osteopontin), which differentially expressed (upregulated) in all the 5 previous studies. 27 Bioinformatics made it possible to collect a total of 45 microarray samples of human endometrium from 3 independent studies. 17,22,23 The collection caused an increase in sample volume to some degree, the bioinformatics algorithm provided by GeneSifter and IPA solved the high-dimension disaster, and the results were more robust and credible than the data from the single center. In this study, we attempted to extract valuable information from the previous data which would not only avoid unnecessary redundancy but also reach a reliable conclusion.

sec.title: Microarray Data Mining for the Differentially Expressed Genes
sec.p: In total, 1543 gene sets were identified as spatial–temporal expression in MSE and significantly varied 2-fold with respect to PE stage. The number of the differentially expressed genes we detected was larger than that of the previous studies using platform Affymetrix HG-U95A, 14 –16,28,29 in which only 100 to 800 differentially expressed genes were found. The possible reason was that we used Affymetrix HG-U133A plus 2.0 with more well-characterized human genes than those of Affymetrix HG-U95A and with different false discovery rates.

The results of PCA indicated that the profile of gene expression accorded with the morphology and functional stages of the endometrium during the menstrual cycle. Consistent with previous studies, we detected that secreted phosphoprotein 1 (osteopontin) upregulated more than 12-fold in MSE in comparison with PE. However, it did not involve in our resultant list of highly upregulated genes for it peaked in LSE. This does not mean that osteopontin played no role in the endometrial receptivity because it significantly upregulated in MSE; however, it might not be a unique marker of the window of implantation, for it still rose after the implantation window. The same was true for leukemia inhibitory factor (LIF), a secreted glycoprotein widely considered to play an important role in the process of embryo implantation. 30 –32 In the current study, LIF was also detected to peak in LSE but was not a desirable marker for the transient implantation window.

The results of hierarchical cluster manifested the expression profile of the genes, those regulating significantly and being specific in MSE as well (Figure 2). In the list of the top regulated genes, some genes had previously been reported, such as S100 calcium-binding protein P. 33,34 Dickkopf homolog 1, 35,36 and monoamine oxidase A. 16,36 Although the mechanism of these genes in the process of endometrial receptivity remains unclear, their spatial–temporal expression in MSE indicated that as potential biomarkers they might be critical to endometrial receptivity.

On the other hand, some genes were rarely reported, such as FAM148A, whose expression level in MSE was nearly as high as 95-fold in PE and as high as 1.7-fold in LSE. Both FAM148A and FAM148B, the 2 members of family with sequence similarity 148, also known as C2CD4A/C2CD4B (encoding C2 calcium-dependent domain containing 4) or NLF1/2 (encoding nuclear localized factor), were upregulated in MSE. They were located at 15q22.2 and encoded nuclear factors characterized by regulating and controlling cellular architecture. 37 Functional roles of FAM148A/B-encoded proteins were not well defined, and the convincing proof of FAM148A/B involved in endometrial receptivity was lacking. However, the expression of FAM148A/B in epithelial cells had been shown to be increased by treatment with proinflammatory cytokines and thus enhancing vascular permeability. 38

Another significantly upregulated group was solute carrier (SLC) family, a group of membrane transport proteins, in which 9 members—functioning as transporting gluamate, neutral amino acid, and proton oligopeptide—were found to increase over 5-fold (Table 2), while only SLC family 47, member 1—functioning as multidrug and toxin extrusion—was significantly downregulated. Although the reports about the SLC groups related to endometrial receptivity were limited, several members of this family markedly changed in the window of implantation, suggesting that they might play a vital role in the process.

sec.title: The Functional Analysis of the Differentially Expressed Genes
sec.p: The results of ontology and function analysis accorded with the morphological and physiological alterations of the endometrium on the window of implantation, during which the endometrium stopped thickening, became more vascular and edematous and the glands displayed enhanced secretory activity. Thus, many of these differentially expressed genes attached themselves to the diseases with the similar biological processes, such as cancer, reproductive system diseases, and gastrointestinal diseases.

The chromosome analysis revealed that the differentially expressed genes were assembled in chromosomes 4, 9, and 14. Many reports showed that abnormal chromosome could disturb the development of preimplantation embryo, 39,40 but limited publications reported the effect of chromosome on endometrial receptivity. It had been found that patients with a complete or partial deficiency of an X chromosome developed an increase in early implantation failure after oocyte donation, which indicated an inherent endometrial abnormality concerned with a deficiency of X-linked genes. 41 Thus, it cannot exclude the possibility that chromosome and autosome may affect the endometrial receptivity, although it needs to be proved.

sec.title: The Canonical Pathways and Network Analysis
sec.p: The analysis of canonical pathways revealed that the complement system, part of the innate immune system, has been widely activated. Many studies have shown that complement regulatory proteins were among the most highly regulated genes in mid-secretory endometrium.14,17,35,42,43 Recent studies have indicated that controlled local complement activation promoted embryo development and was involved in the physiological remodeling of the spiral arteries. 44 The other highly regulated canonical pathway was mitotic roles of Plk pathway, but it was widely inactivated in contrast with the complement system. Polo-like kinases, a family of conserved serine/threonine kinases, were reported to be involved in the regulation of cell cycle progression through G2 and M (mitosis). The downregulation of genes in this pathway was in accordance with the results of functional analysis that the biological processes of downregulated genes were mainly directed to cell cycle.

Moreover, two significant networks, related to the cardiovascular system development and cancer, have been identified using the top regulated genes (over 10-fold). The two networks were found to include cell-signaling pathways such as the smad2/3 pathway, Erk 1/2 pathway, and Akt pathway, as well as cell-signaling molecules such as nuclear interferon gamma, histone H3, TP53, and so on. According to network theories and studies of yeast cells, the genes in a network center and having the maximum number of connections play a key regulatory role. 21 In our study, TGFB1, TNF, ERBB2, and FSH, CTNNB1, ESR1, located at the centers of the two networks, respectively, were highly connected. The findings can provide important clues for further studies of the mechanism of endometrial receptivity.

Real-time PCR validated that the selected genes exhibited a high consistence with GeneSifter results, which proved the veracity and feasibility of our methods. Within the validated genes, some were widely accepted; however, some were rarely mapped, such as FAM148A, ANAX4 (Annexin IV), SFN (stratifin, also known as 14-3-3 sigma), CRISP3 (cysteine-rich secretory protein 3), and SFRP4 (secreted frizzled-related protein 4). The expression profile of these genes can be of great importance to further studies.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In summary, our study took advantage of existing data from microarray database, using bioinformatics tools, exhibiting a series of potential biomarkers specific to receptive endometrium, exploring their functions, pathways, and networks to pursue the mechanism of endometrial receptivity, and finding chromosomes 4, 9, and 14 being highly related to endometrial receptivity. Real-time PCR validated the expressions of 9 genes and proved the veracity and feasibility of our methods. Our study initiated such research in a meaningful way, even though further studies are needed to substantiate the results for clinical applications.

fn.label: Declaration of Conflicting Interests
fn.p: The author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This work was supported by grants from the Natural Science Foundation of China (NSFC, 30271354) and Shanghai Medical Science Bootstrap Class Project (10411960600). The funders had no role in study design, data collection and analysis, decision to publish, or preparation of the manuscript.
